A number `p` is prime if and only if there exists an `a` such that
`a^(p-1) = 1 mod p` and `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`.

type: ∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p ↔ ∃ a, a ^ (p - 1) = 1 ∧ ∀ (q : ℕ), Nat.Prime q → q ∣ p - 1 → a ^ ((p - 1) / q) ≠ 1
name: lucas_primality_iff
docString:
A number `p` is prime if and only if there exists an `a` such that
`a^(p-1) = 1 mod p` and `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`.

A natural number `p` is prime if and only if `p` is greater than 1 and has no divisors other than 1 and `p`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime ↔ 2 ≤ p ∧ ∀ (m : ℕ), m ∣ p → m = 1 ∨ m = p
name: Nat.prime_def_lt''
docString: A natural number `p` is prime if and only if `p` is greater than 1 and has no divisors other than 1 and `p`.

This theorem states that for any natural number `p` that is prime, and any other natural number `m`, if `m` divides `p` then `m` must be either `1` or `p` itself. This is a property of prime numbers, which are defined as natural numbers greater than or equal to 2 that have no other divisors except for `1` and themselves.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime → ∀ (m : ℕ), m ∣ p → m = 1 ∨ m = p
name: Nat.Prime.eq_one_or_self_of_dvd
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `p` that is prime, and any other natural number `m`, if `m` divides `p` then `m` must be either `1` or `p` itself. This is a property of prime numbers, which are defined as natural numbers greater than or equal to 2 that have no other divisors except for `1` and themselves.

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → p.factorization = fun₀ | p => 1
name: Nat.Prime.factorization
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

A natural number `p` is prime if and only if `p` is greater than or equal to 2 and the smallest prime factor of `p` is `p`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime ↔ 2 ≤ p ∧ p.minFac = p
name: Nat.prime_def_minFac
docString: A natural number `p` is prime if and only if `p` is greater than or equal to 2 and the smallest prime factor of `p` is `p`.

This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime → p.properDivisors = {1}
name: Nat.Prime.properDivisors
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

A natural number not divible by `p` has absolute value 1.

name: Rat.MulRingNorm.mulRingNorm_eq_one_of_not_dvd
docString: A natural number not divible by `p` has absolute value 1.

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

type: ∀ {p q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → p.factorization q ≠ 0 → p = q
name: Nat.Prime.eq_of_factorization_pos
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → p.factorization p = 1
name: Nat.Prime.factorization_self
docString: The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

type: ∀ {k p : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Nat.Prime p → (p ^ k).primeFactors = {p}
name: Nat.primeFactors_prime_pow
docString: The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

`Nat.Prime p` means that `p` is a prime number, that is, a natural number
at least 2 whose only divisors are `p` and `1`.
The theorem `Nat.prime_def` witnesses this description of a prime number.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p ↔ 2 ≤ p ∧ ∀ (m : ℕ), m ∣ p → m = 1 ∨ m = p
name: Nat.prime_def
docString:
`Nat.Prime p` means that `p` is a prime number, that is, a natural number
at least 2 whose only divisors are `p` and `1`.
The theorem `Nat.prime_def` witnesses this description of a prime number.

If `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`, but `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`, then `p`
is prime. This is true because `a` has order `p-1` in the multiplicative group mod `p`, so this
group must itself have order `p-1`, which only happens when `p` is prime.

type: ∀ (p : ℕ) (a : ZMod p), a ^ (p - 1) = 1 → (∀ (q : ℕ), Nat.Prime q → q ∣ p - 1 → a ^ ((p - 1) / q) ≠ 1) → Nat.Prime p
name: lucas_primality
docString:
If `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`, but `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`, then `p`
is prime. This is true because `a` has order `p-1` in the multiplicative group mod `p`, so this
group must itself have order `p-1`, which only happens when `p` is prime.

When `p` is prime, then the totient of `p ^ (n + 1)` is `p ^ n * (p - 1)`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → ∀ (n : ℕ), (p ^ (n + 1)).totient = p ^ n * (p - 1)
name: Nat.totient_prime_pow_succ
docString: When `p` is prime, then the totient of `p ^ (n + 1)` is `p ^ n * (p - 1)`

A prime `p` is a unit in a finite commutative ring `R`
iff it does not divide the characteristic.

type:
∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : CommRing R] (p : ℕ) [inst_1 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [inst_2 : Finite R],
  IsUnit ↑p ↔ ¬p ∣ ringChar R
name: isUnit_iff_not_dvd_char
docString:
A prime `p` is a unit in a finite commutative ring `R`
iff it does not divide the characteristic.

The set of positive powers of prime `p` that divide `n` is exactly the set of
positive natural numbers up to `n.factorization p`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ) {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → Finset.Icc 1 (n.factorization p) = Finset.filter (fun i => p ^ i ∣ n) (Finset.Ico 1 n)
name: Nat.Icc_factorization_eq_pow_dvd
docString:
The set of positive powers of prime `p` that divide `n` is exactly the set of
positive natural numbers up to `n.factorization p`.

A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p ≠ 2`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p % 2 = 1 ↔ p ≠ 2
name: Nat.Prime.mod_two_eq_one_iff_ne_two
docString: A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p ≠ 2`.

For prime `p` the only prime factor of `p^k` is `p` with multiplicity `k`

type: ∀ {p k : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → (p ^ k).factorization = fun₀ | p => k
name: Nat.Prime.factorization_pow
docString: For prime `p` the only prime factor of `p^k` is `p` with multiplicity `k`

A prime `p` is a unit in a commutative ring `R` of nonzero characteristic iff it does not divide
the characteristic.

type:
∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : CommRing R] (p : ℕ) [inst_1 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  ringChar R ≠ 0 → (IsUnit ↑p ↔ ¬p ∣ ringChar R)
name: isUnit_iff_not_dvd_char_of_ringChar_ne_zero
docString:
A prime `p` is a unit in a commutative ring `R` of nonzero characteristic iff it does not divide
the characteristic.

When `p` is prime, then the totient of `p ^ n` is `p ^ (n - 1) * (p - 1)`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → ∀ {n : ℕ}, 0 < n → (p ^ n).totient = p ^ (n - 1) * (p - 1)
name: Nat.totient_prime_pow
docString: When `p` is prime, then the totient of `p ^ n` is `p ^ (n - 1) * (p - 1)`

If `1 < p`, then `q p`, the smallest prime factor of `mersenne p`, is more than 2.

type: ∀ (p' : ℕ), 2 < LucasLehmer.q (p' + 2)
name: LucasLehmer.two_lt_q
docString: If `1 < p`, then `q p`, the smallest prime factor of `mersenne p`, is more than 2.

If `p` is prime, then there exists an `a` such that `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`
and `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`.
The multiplicative group mod `p` is cyclic, so `a` can be any generator of the group
(which must have order `p-1`).

type: ∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → ∃ a, a ^ (p - 1) = 1 ∧ ∀ (q : ℕ), Nat.Prime q → q ∣ p - 1 → a ^ ((p - 1) / q) ≠ 1
name: reverse_lucas_primality
docString:
If `p` is prime, then there exists an `a` such that `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`
and `a^((p-1)/q) ≠ 1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`.
The multiplicative group mod `p` is cyclic, so `a` can be any generator of the group
(which must have order `p-1`).

`ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ+} {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] {ζ : K} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime ↑p)] [inst_1 : CharZero K]
  [h : IsCyclotomicExtension {p} ℚ K] (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ ↑p), Prime (hζ.toInteger - 1)
name: IsPrimitiveRoot.zeta_sub_one_prime'
docString: `ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

For a prime number `p`, taking `(p - 1)` times the multiplicity of `p` in `n!` equals `n` minus
the sum of base `p` digits of `n`.

type: ∀ {n p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → (p - 1) * multiplicity p n.factorial = n - (p.digits n).sum
name: Nat.Prime.sub_one_mul_multiplicity_factorial
docString:
For a prime number `p`, taking `(p - 1)` times the multiplicity of `p` in `n!` equals `n` minus
the sum of base `p` digits of `n`.

If `p` is a prime and `a` is an integer, then `a : ZMod p` is zero if and only if
`gcd a p ≠ 1`.

type: ∀ {a : ℤ} {p : ℕ} [pp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], ↑a = 0 ↔ a.gcd ↑p ≠ 1
name: ZMod.eq_zero_iff_gcd_ne_one
docString:
If `p` is a prime and `a` is an integer, then `a : ZMod p` is zero if and only if
`gcd a p ≠ 1`.
